title: Case Study: A 65-year-old Male with Parkinson's Disease
clinical_history: A 65-year-old male, Mr. Johnson, presents with a 5-year history of Parkinson's disease. He was initially diagnosed with tremors in his right hand, which progressed to rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability. He experiences difficulty with walking, balance, and performing daily activities due to his symptoms. He has a history of falls, with the most recent one occurring 6 months ago, resulting in a fractured right wrist. He also reports experiencing pain and stiffness in his neck, shoulders, and lower back.
aggrevating_factors: Prolonged standing, walking, or sitting; turning in bed; and getting in and out of a car
picture: A 24-hour picture of Mr. Johnson shows that his symptoms worsen throughout the day, with increased rigidity and tremors in the afternoon. He also experiences nocturnal pain and stiffness, which disrupts his sleep.
easing_factors: Rest, physical therapy, and medication; specifically, his symptoms improve with dopaminergic medication, but the effects wear off after 2-3 hours
past_history: Hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a remote history of smoking
medical_history: Diagnosed with Parkinson's disease 5 years ago; recently started experiencing freezing of gait and increased fall risk
medications: Levodopa/carbidopa, ropinirole, and pramipexole; recently started on physical therapy to improve mobility and balance
personal_history: Married with two children; worked as an engineer until his retirement 5 years ago; enjoys reading and spending time with his grandchildren, but has had to adapt his activities due to his symptoms
imaging: MRI of the brain showed no significant abnormalities; X-rays of the neck, shoulders, and lower back showed mild degenerative changes
